metadata.titleEn: AMSR-E/AMSR2 soil moisture and vegetation optical depth product (0.1°) using MCCA (2002-2022)
metadata.description: Soil moisture (SM) plays a vital role in regulating the water and energy exchange between land surfaces and the atmosphere and is declared an essential climate variable by the Global Climate Observing System (GCOS). Vegetation optical depth (VOD) is a crucial parameter describing vegetation attenuation properties in microwave radiative transfer equation, and it has been proven to be a promising ecological indicator for studying plant hydraulics, carbon stocks, and vegetation phenology. A long-term SM and polarization-, frequency-dependent VODs (C/X/Ku) product was derived from the inter-calibrated AMSR-E/2 multi-frequency brightness temperature at a spatial resolution of 0.1 degree, using the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA). The MCCA comprehensively considers the physical relationship between multiple microwave channels and could simultaneously retrieve frequency- and polarization-dependent VODs and SM. The new MCCA AMSR-E/2 SM dataset was validated over 25 dense soil moisture networks from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) watersheds. The results showed that MCCA performs best in terms of ubRMSE among the current publicly available SM datasets related to AMSR-E/2. In addition, polarization-, frequency-dependent VODs from MCCA may provide new insights for better understanding the water fluxes in plant physiology.
metadata.instructions: <MCCA_AMSRE/2_010D_CCXP_VSM_VOD_Des/Asc_YYYYMMDD_V0.nc4> <MCCA> represents the multi-channel collaborative algorithm, <AMSRE/2> represents the AMSR-E sensor or AMSR2 sensor, <010D> represents the spatial resolution of data, <CCXP> indicates X-band brightness temperature at P polarization (P denotes H or V) was used as the core channel in MCCA, VSM_VOD is the product of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth, <Des/Asc> represents the descending orbit or ascending orbit,<YYYYMMDD> is the date, and V0 represents the data version, which will be updated according to your valuable suggestions. Usage method: Data can be read in various programming languages such as MATLAB, Python and IDL, and can also be visualized in HDFView and Panoply. Please refer to the description document for details. We provide MATLAB code to read and plot the data.

background: Surface soil moisture (SM) plays a vital role in regulating water and energy exchanges between land surfaces and the atmosphere and is thus critically important for hydrological modeling, agricultural management, and numerical weather forecasting. Over the past few decades, passive microwave remote sensing has shown great advantages in monitoring SM at global or regional scales due to its high sensitivity to surface dielectric properties and frequent and continuous (all weather) monitoring of the Earth's surface. On the other hand, vegetation optical depth (VOD, τ) is a crucial parameter describing vegetation attenuation properties in the microwave radiative transfer equations (RTE). Although VOD was originally treated as a transition variable for correcting vegetation effects in SM retrieval algorithms, it has been proven to be a promising ecological indicator for studying plant hydraulics, carbon stocks, and vegetation phenology. Long-term and accurate global monitoring of SM and VOD are essential to enhance our knowledge on the linkage between water, and carbon cycles in terrestrial ecosystems. Spaceborne passive microwave technology has experienced rapid development since the Skylab mission in the 1970s. Current spaceborne microwave radiometers can be divided into two categories: (i) multi-frequency radiometers with selected channels from C-band (6.9 GHz) to W-band (89 GHz), and (ii) single-frequency radiometers at L-band (1.4 GHz). Although the L-band has been proven to be the optimal tool for monitoring SM, data of this band are only available for > 10 years with the Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity (SMOS) mission launched in November 2009 and the Soil Moisture Active and Passive (SMAP) launched in January 2015. On the other hand, multi-frequency radiometers at higher frequency bands provide a much longer heritage of measurements, although their sensitivity to SM is weaker than that of L-band. Among those multi-frequency radiometers, two typical spaceborne sensors are the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) and its successor AMSR2. The AMSR-E was in orbit from 2002 to 2011 and carried on the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) satellite Aqua. It is a twelve-channel, six-frequency (from 6.9 to 89 GHz), total power passive-microwave radiometer system. The AMSR2 launched aboard the Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA) Global Change Observation Mission 1st-Water (GCOM-W1) satellite on May 18, 2012, is configured with instrument attributes (frequency band, incidence angle, etc.) similar to AMSR-E. The combined use of AMSR-E/2/3 brightness temperature (TB) observations could generate long-term data of SM and VOD, which are valuable for climate change studies. Concurrent with the development of passive microwave spaceborne missions, the scientific community has also made large efforts for improving the retrieval methodology of SM and VOD at the global scale. Most SM and VOD retrievals designed for AMSR-E/2 are based on the tau-omega model, which is the zero-order solution of RTE by neglecting multiple scattering between vegetation and the surface.
research objective: In this study, a new global SM and frequency- and polarization-dependent VOD product from 2002 to 2021 was developed using the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA), based on the inter-calibrated AMSR-E/2 multi-frequency passive microwave measurements. It is expected that the MCCA algorithm can be extended to the observations of the ongoing AMSR2 or other similar satellite missions with multi-frequency capability, such as FY-3B/C/D/F/G or the upcoming AMSR3 and CMIR missions.
challenges: Most of the current retrieval algorithms either only focus on SM or VOD, and generally ignore the polarization or simplify the frequency dependence of vegetation effects for reducing the unknowns and facilitating the retrieval process, limiting the synergic applicability of VOD and SM products in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum.
methods: In this study, multi-frequency gridded L3 TB products from AMSR-E/2 were used to retrieve SM and VOD. To ensure the data consistency between the two sensors, we adopted a similar strategy as Yao et al. (2021) for TB inter-calibration. The harmonized multi-frequency TB data (2002–2021) was then used to generate long-term SM and VOD product. To effectively validate the retrieved SM, ground-based measurements from 25 dense networks were used. In this study, we extended MCCA to the AMSR-E/2 configurations at the global scale. For the implementation of MCCA, the effective soil temperature was estimated using the Ka-band (37 GHz) observations according to the method of Holmes et al. (2009). To account for the surface roughness effect, we used the Qp model proposed by Shi et al. (2005) in this study.
dataset: In this study, multi-frequency gridded L3 TB products from AMSR-E/2 were used to retrieve SM and VOD. The harmonized multi-frequency TB data (2002–2021) was then used to generate long-term SM and VOD product. To effectively validate the retrieved SM, ground-based measurements from 25 dense networks were used. These SM networks are from the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN), the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) watersheds, and the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (TPDC). Unlike SM, VOD is treated as a transition variable in RTE rather than an intuitive and easily measured parameter. In this context, this study used aboveground biomass (AGB) and NDVI to indirectly evaluate the MCCA-derived VODs, the standard LPRM products from NASA, and the VODCA product.
findings: In the overall comparison with other SM products (AMSR-ANN, CCI-passive v07.1, LPRM-C/X, JAXA) over 25 dense SM networks, MCCA achieved the best scores in terms of root mean square error (RMSE = 0.074 m3/m3), unbiased root mean square error (ubRMSE = 0.073 m3/m3) and bias (0.007 m3/m3), and presented slightly lower value of Pearson’s correlation coefficient (R = 0.709) than LPRM-X (R = 0.735). For the indirect evaluation of VOD with aboveground biomass (AGB) and MODIS NDVI, the MCCA product showed the performance comparable to other products (LPRM-C/X, VODCA-C/X/Ku). MCCA-derived VODs, especially for the H-polarized VODs, exhibited smooth non-linear density distribution with AGB and high temporal correlations with MODIS NDVI over most regions of the globe. In particular, MCCA-derived VODs can physically present reasonable variations across the microwave spectrum (values of VOD increase with microwave frequency), which is superior to the LPRM and VODCA products.

background: Due to the success of the SMOS (Soil Moisture and Ocean Salinity) and SMAP (Soil Moisture Active Passive) missions, new satellite missions are on the horizon. The current and future missions can benefit from investigations that seek to improve retrieval algorithms that quantitatively map global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth (tau) from Earth’s microwave emissions.
research objective: In this study, we explore multi-angular and multi-frequency approaches for the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation tau, considering the payload configurations of current and future satellite missions (such as the Copernicus Imaging Microwave Radiometer, the Water Cycle Observation Mission, and the Terrestrial Water Resources Satellite) using a new set of ground observations.
challenges: It is affirmed that increasing the number of observation channels could make the soil moisture retrieval more robust, but might also limit the retrieval performance, as the probability that the model estimations will not match the observations is increased.
methods: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study. A multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is developed based on the two-component version of the omega-tau model, which utilizes information from collaborative channels expressed as an analytical form of brightness temperature at the core channel to rule out the parameters to be retrieved.
dataset: Two ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected in Inner Mongolia during the Soil Moisture Experiment in the Luan River from July to August 2017 (cropland) and August to September 2018 (grassland) are used for this study.
findings: Results of soil moisture retrieval show that the multi-angular approach used by the MCCA generally has a better performance, unbiased root mean square difference (ubRMSD) varying from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.037 cm³/cm³, than the multi-frequency approach (ubRMSD from 0.028 cm³/cm³ to 0.089 cm³/cm³) for the corn field. Except for in the C- & X-band combination, the multi-frequency approach used by the MCCA performs better (ubRMSD from 0.018 cm³/cm³ to 0.023 cm³/cm³) than the multi-angular version (ubRMSD from 0.026 cm³/cm³ to 0.034 cm³/cm³) for the grass field due to reduced vegetation effects for this type of cover. This study provides new insights into the design of potential satellite missions to improve soil moisture retrieval. A satellite with simultaneous multi-angular and multi-frequency observation capabilities is highly recommended.

Definition.Question: What is the multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) in the context of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Definition.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is a method used to retrieve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth by considering multiple channels' physical relationships. It simultaneously accounts for frequency and polarization differences to better assess these variables.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges associated with using multi-frequency radiometers for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Definition.Answer: One of the challenges with using multi-frequency radiometers is that many retrieval algorithms focus solely on either soil moisture or vegetation optical depth. They often ignore polarization or simplify the frequency dependence of vegetation effects, which limits the synergic applicability of VOD and SM products in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do ground-based microwave radiometry datasets differ in their utility and results when compared to spaceborne datasets like those from AMSR-E/2 for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Comparison.Answer: Ground-based microwave radiometry datasets collected during specific soil moisture experiments provide detailed local measurements that can be used to test retrieval algorithms such as MCCA, which showed varying performance depending on the type of land cover. In contrast, spaceborne datasets like AMSR-E/2 offer global coverage and long-term data, which are essential for large-scale climate studies and are validated using networks such as the International Soil Moisture Network.

Interpretation.Question: How might the use of multi-frequency and polarization-dependent retrieval algorithms enhance the understanding of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth interactions in global climate models?
Interpretation.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) considers multiple frequency and polarization channels, allowing for the simultaneous retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth. By doing so, it provides detailed insights into the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum and helps to refine the models used in global climate studies, especially in understanding the interactions between water and carbon cycles in terrestrial ecosystems.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the harmonization of brightness temperature data from different sensors impact the development of long-term soil moisture and vegetation optical depth datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The harmonization of brightness temperature data from sensors such as AMSR-E and AMSR2 ensures consistency across datasets over extended periods. This consistency is vital for developing reliable long-term records of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth, which are essential for tracking climate change impacts and improving ecological and hydrological models.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes challenges in the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using multi-frequency radiometers?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in the retrieval process stem from the focus on either soil moisture or vegetation optical depth while generally ignoring polarization or simplifying the frequency dependence of vegetation effects. This limits the synergic applicability of the data within the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it necessary to inter-calibrate brightness temperature data between different satellite sensors for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Inter-calibration is necessary to ensure data consistency between different sensors like AMSR-E and AMSR2. This harmonization allows for the generation of long-term datasets that are crucial for studying soil moisture and vegetation optical depth accurately across different time periods and sensor platforms.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) on the retrieval accuracy of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth from microwave radiometry data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) can enhance the retrieval accuracy of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth by simultaneously considering frequency and polarization differences. This approach results in a reduction of the unbiased root mean square error (ubRMSE) for soil moisture retrieval, making it superior to other existing algorithms. Additionally, it provides improved data consistency and enables the generation of long-term datasets that are valuable for climate change studies.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of utilizing multiple frequency bands and polarization differences in the development of vegetation optical depth products?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Utilizing multiple frequency bands and polarization differences in the development of vegetation optical depth products allows for a more nuanced understanding of vegetation attenuation properties across different microwave frequencies. This approach leads to improved representation of physical variations in vegetation over the microwave spectrum, providing insights into plant hydraulics and biomass studies. It enhances the applicability of the products for ecological and agricultural research by offering data with higher temporal correlations and smoother density distributions compared to other methods.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the ultimate goal behind developing a global soil moisture and vegetation optical depth product using multi-channel collaborative algorithms with AMSR-E/AMSR2 data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The ultimate goal is to create a long-term global product that accurately captures soil moisture and frequency- and polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth (VOD) using inter-calibrated multi-frequency passive microwave measurements. This aims to enhance understanding of the water and carbon cycles in terrestrial ecosystems and improve the applicability of VOD and soil moisture products in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What specific procedures are followed to ensure data consistency and accuracy when retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth using multi-frequency passive microwave measurements?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To ensure data consistency and accuracy when retrieving soil moisture and vegetation optical depth, a strategy similar to TB inter-calibration is adopted. Harmonized multi-frequency TB data from AMSR-E/2 is utilized to generate long-term products, and effective soil temperature is estimated using Ka-band observations. The Qp model is used to account for surface roughness effects. Ground-based measurements from dense networks are used for validation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can a multi-channel collaborative algorithm be extended to new satellite missions with multi-frequency capabilities to improve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrievals?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: A multi-channel collaborative algorithm can be extended to new satellite missions with multi-frequency capabilities by utilizing the inter-calibrated multi-frequency passive microwave measurements. The algorithm accounts for the physical relationships between multiple channels and could be adapted to missions like FY-3B/C/D/F/G or upcoming AMSR3 and CMIR missions. This extension would involve harmonizing TB data and adapting the retrieval methodology accordingly.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methods are used to validate soil moisture retrievals from satellite data using ground-based observations, and what are the challenges associated with these methods?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Soil moisture retrievals from satellite data are validated using ground-based measurements from 25 dense networks, including the International Soil Moisture Network, USDA watersheds, and the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center. Challenges include ensuring compatibility between satellite and ground observations, addressing variations in soil and vegetation types, and accounting for differences in measurement scales and temporal resolution.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the development of multi-frequency passive microwave measurements for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth data collection?
Enablement.Answer: The development of spaceborne passive microwave radiometers such as AMSR-E and AMSR2, which are equipped with multi-frequency capabilities ranging from C-band to Ku-band, have enabled the collection of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth data. These advancements allow for the long-term monitoring of surface soil moisture and vegetation parameters globally, leveraging the sensitivity of microwave frequencies to dielectric properties and vegetation attenuation.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the validation of satellite-derived soil moisture products using ground-based measurements?
Enablement.Answer: The validation of satellite-derived soil moisture products is enabled through the use of ground-based measurements from dense observational networks such as the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN) and the USDA watersheds. These networks provide reliable reference data that facilitate the evaluation of the accuracy and reliability of satellite-derived products by comparing them to in-situ measurements, ensuring the robustness of the retrieval methodologies.

Expectation.Question: Why might the use of multi-frequency radiometers be expected to improve the retrieval of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth, despite potential challenges with model estimations?
Expectation.Answer: The use of multi-frequency radiometers is expected to improve retrieval because they provide a longer heritage of measurements and can account for frequency-dependent vegetation effects. However, increasing observation channels could make retrieval more robust but might also limit performance due to mismatches between model estimations and observations.

Expectation.Question: Why is there an expectation for the multi-channel collaborative algorithm to be extended to other satellite missions with similar capabilities?
Expectation.Answer: The expectation for extending the multi-channel collaborative algorithm to other satellite missions arises from its ability to utilize multi-frequency capability effectively, which can be applied to similar satellites like FY-3B/C/D/F/G or upcoming missions like AMSR3 and CMIR. This extension is feasible because the algorithm can handle multi-frequency observations for both soil moisture and vegetation optical depth retrieval.

Judgmental.Question: How effective do you think multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) is in overcoming the traditional challenges of retrieving both soil moisture and vegetation optical depth concurrently from satellite data?
Judgmental.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) appears to be effective in addressing the challenge of retrieving both soil moisture and vegetation optical depth concurrently, as it considers the physical relationships between multiple channels. This approach allows for the simultaneous retrieval of frequency and polarization-dependent vegetation optical depth and soil moisture, thus enhancing the synergic applicability of these products in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum.

Judgmental.Question: What is your evaluation of the potential for using aboveground biomass and NDVI to indirectly assess vegetation optical depth, and how reliable are such approaches in providing insights into vegetation dynamics?
Judgmental.Answer: Using aboveground biomass and NDVI to indirectly assess vegetation optical depth is a promising approach, as it allows for the evaluation of VOD products in terms of their correlation with vegetation dynamics. This method has shown comparable performance to other products, offering reliable insights into temporal and spatial variations in vegetation density and dynamics, especially when combined with microwave frequency data.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how multi-channel collaborative algorithms can simultaneously retrieve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth effectively.
Assertion.Answer: The multi-channel collaborative algorithm (MCCA) utilizes inter-calibrated multi-frequency passive microwave measurements to simultaneously retrieve soil moisture and vegetation optical depth. It considers multiple channels' physical relationships to effectively capture frequency and polarization differences, allowing for a more comprehensive retrieval process.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how vegetation optical depth is evaluated when it is not an intuitive or easily measured parameter.
Assertion.Answer: Vegetation optical depth is evaluated indirectly using aboveground biomass (AGB) and NDVI. The multi-channel collaborative algorithm-derived VODs are compared with these proxies to ensure reasonable variations across the microwave spectrum and high temporal correlations with NDVI, providing insights into vegetation attenuation properties.

Request/Directive.Question: Please describe the data collection methods used to ensure the consistency of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth measurements across different sensors and time periods.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection method involved using multi-frequency gridded L3 TB products from AMSR-E/2, ensuring data consistency between the two sensors through inter-calibration strategies. Ground-based measurements from 25 dense networks were used to validate the retrieved soil moisture, employing the harmonized multi-frequency TB data from 2002 to 2021.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the challenges faced in developing retrieval algorithms that can effectively utilize multi-frequency and polarization-dependent data for soil moisture and vegetation optical depth measurements.
Request/Directive.Answer: The challenges include the fact that most current retrieval algorithms focus either only on soil moisture or vegetation optical depth, often ignoring polarization or simplifying the frequency dependence of vegetation effects. This simplification is typically done to reduce unknowns and facilitate the retrieval process, which limits the synergic applicability of soil moisture and vegetation optical depth products in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets or sources that can be used to validate soil moisture retrievals and assess vegetation optical depth in relation to aboveground biomass and NDVI.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for validating soil moisture retrievals include ground-based measurements from networks such as the International Soil Moisture Network (ISMN), the United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) watersheds, and the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center (TPDC). Vegetation optical depth can be assessed indirectly using aboveground biomass (AGB) and NDVI, comparing MCCA-derived VODs with standard LPRM products from NASA and the VODCA product.
